questions.question: A patient presents with a fever and a red, tender, swollen left knee, which started two days ago. He was recently diagnosed with hypertension and started on hydrochlorothiazide. Immediate joint aspiration is done, and the microscopic picture is given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?
Which of the following drugs treats an acute episode of gout by binding to synovial tubulin thus inhibiting the migration of granulocytes into the joint ?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Colchicine Explanation: Colchicine is the drug that acts by binding to the fibrillary protein tubulin , thus inhibiting the migration of granulocytes into the joint ( naproxen and piroxicam share the exact mechanism of action). Mechanism of action of colchicine: Reference: KD Tripathi Essentials of Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page 231, 232

questions.question: Which of the following drugs is not used in the management of chronic hyperuricemia?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Etoricoxib Explanation: Etoricoxib , which is an NSAID, will not be used in chronic hyperuricemia/chronic gout. Instead, it can be used to treat acute gout attacks. Chronic gout: Persistence of pain and stiffness in joints in between the attacks. Other cardinal features are hyperuricemia, tophi, and urate stones in the kidney. In most cases, hyperuricemia is due to the under-secretion of uric acid, while in a few, it is due to overproduction. Chronic gouty arthritis may cause progressive deformities and permanent disabilities. Drugs used in chronic gout: Uricosurics: They increase uric acid excretion. Drugs: Probenecid, sulfinpyrazone, lesinurad, benzbromarone. Uric acid synthesis inhibitors: They inhibit xanthine oxidase, inhibiting uric acid synthesis. (Options B & c ruled out) Allopurinol, febuxostat. (Option D ruled out) Reference: KD Tripathi essentials of pharmacology 8th edition, Page 231, 232

questions.question: A patient complains of persistent pain and stiffness over both his big toes and right knee over the past 2 years. X-ray of big toe showed deposition of uric acid crystals. Which of the following is the most appropriate drug of choice to reduce uric acid levels?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Allopurinol Explanation: The given clinical scenario, along with the x-ray findings of the big toe, showing deposition of uric acid crystals, is suggestive of chronic gout and allopurinol is the most appropriate drug of choice among the given options. Rat bite erosions , also known as Martel sign or G sign , are seen in gout and refer to punched out erosions with sclerotic and overhanging margins. Allopurinol: Allopurinol was initially synthesized as an antineoplastic agent, but was later found to lack anti-cancer property, but an inhibitor of xanthine oxidase (XO). Both allopurinol and its primary metabolite, oxypurinol (alloxanthine) , reduce urate production by inhibiting XO, the enzyme that converts xanthine to uric acid. Allopurinol competitively inhibits XO at low concentrations and is a non-competitive inhibitor at high concentrations. It is the drug of choice for treatment of chronic gout , however there is a risk of acute attack in the beginning due to compensatory mobilisation of tissue stores into plasma. Hence, colchicine or NSAIDs are given along with in the beginning. Other uses of allopurinol: Tumour lysis syndrome. Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. Post-transplant patients. Piroxicam , E toricoxib (NSAIDS) and H ydrocortisone (steroids), are used in the management of acute gout attacks. ( Options A, C and D ruled out) Reference: KD Tripathi Essentials of Pharmacology, 8th Edition, Page 232. Goodman and Gilman's The pharmacological basis of therapeutics, 14th Edition, Page 848, 849

questions.question: All of the following about allopurinol are incorrect except?

options.B: Allopurinol is largely bound to plasma proteins.
options.C: Allopurinol reduces the activity of azathioprine.

questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Allopurinol is contraindicated during lactation. Explanation: Pharmacokinetics of allopurinol: Allopurinol (half-life of 2 hours ) is shorter acting than its metabolite alloxanthine (half-life of 24 hours ). (Option A) 80% of orally administered allopurinol is absorbed orally; it is not bound to plasma proteins and is metabolised to xanthine (Option B). Drug interactions: Allopurinol inhibits the degradation of 6-mercaptopurine and azathioprine, increasing their concentrations (Option C). Probenecid + allopurinol: Probenecid shortens the t1/2 of allopurinol. Allopurinol prolongs the t1/2 of probenecid. Allopurinol can potentiate warfarin and theophylline by inhibiting their metabolism. Allopurinol + ampicillin: Higher incidence of skin rashes. Contraindications: Hypersensitivity, pregnancy, and lactation (Option D). Cautious use is recommended in Extremes of age. Patients with kidney and liver disease. Reference: KD Tripathi Essentials of Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page 233-235

questions.question: A 48-year-old man with a history of chronic gout presented with recurrent episodes of painful attacks despite being on allopurinol. His physician suggests a drug that inhibits the reabsorption of uric acid in the proximal tubules. Which of the following drugs uses this mechanism of action?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Probenicid Explanation : Probenecid inhibits the URAT1 transporter in the proximal convoluted tubule, thereby reducing reabsorption of uric acid and increasing its excretion. It is classified as a uricosuric agent , effective in patients who under-excrete uric acid. It is useful in chronic gout, particularly when allopurinol or febuxostat alone is insufficient. Mechanisms of Action of Common Anti-Gout Drugs: Drug Class Mechanism of Action Use Probenecid Uricosuric agent Inhibits URAT1 transporter → ↓ uric acid reabsorption → ↑ excretion Chronic gout (under-excretors) Febuxostat Xanthine oxidase inhibitor Inhibits xanthine oxidase → ↓ uric acid production Chronic gout Rasburicase Uricolytic agent Converts uric acid to allantoin (soluble) Tumor lysis syndrome Colchicine Anti-inflammatory Inhibits microtubule polymerization → ↓ neutrophil activity Acute gout attacks Febuxostat (Option B): Incorrect because it inhibits xanthine oxidase , not uric acid reabsorption. Rasburicase (Option C): Incorrect because it converts uric acid to allantoin , used in tumor lysis syndrome, not chronic gout. Colchicine (Option D): Incorrect because it acts by inhibiting neutrophil chemotaxis and is used for acute gout , not for reducing uric acid levels chronically. Reference: Goodman and Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th Edition, Page 847-852

questions.question: A 75-year-old male with a history of gout presents to the clinic with increased frequency of gout attacks. His daily medications include rosuvastatin, low-dose aspirin and losartan for hypertension. He has been advised to avoid certain medications that can exacerbate his gout. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient?
questions.explanation: (blocking urate reabsorption). Low doses (<2 g/day): Uric acid retention (inhibiting urate secretion). Gout triggers can include alcohol, red meat and certain medications. Drugs Associated with Gout Drugs causing gout Drugs beneficial in gout Mnemonic – PAINED P : Pyrazinamide A: Aspirin (Normal dose <2 gms) I : Immunosuppressive: Cyclosporine N : Niacin E : Ethambutol D : Diuretic like loop diuretics, thiazides Mnemonic – FALSe F : Fenofibrate A : Aspirin in toxic dose >5 gm L : Losartan (OPTION B) Se : Statins (Pravastatin, rosuvastatin) (OPTION D) Treatment for drug-induced gout: Continue the drug + Allopurinol. Note : Allopurinol (Option A) benefits gout by reducing uric acid production by inhibiting xanthine oxidase. Reference: Goodman and Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th Edition, Page 33, 734-737, 1271.

questions.question: A 42-year-old female presented to the hospital with early morning stiffness in her joints for the last few weeks. She reports severe pain in her right wrist and left knee. Increased CRP levels are seen in laboratory testing. What is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) NSAIDs Explanation: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA): Type 3 and 4 hypersensitivity common in a middle-aged female. Symptoms: Early morning stiffness, pain, redness and swelling. Joints involved: MCP, ICP and knee. Management: Treatment of Rheumatoid Arthritis Acute arthritis Mild-moderate DOC: NSAIDs(OPTION B) All except paracetamol (Piroxicam, Indomethacin, Aspirin, Diclofenac, Celecoxib 2. Severe flare/ Resistant to NSAIDS 1-2 joints: Intra-articular corticosteroids (Prednisolone, Triamcinolone) >2 joints: Oral prednisolone Long-term definitive treatment DMARDs (Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs) DOC: Methotrexate (OPTION A) Alternate: Hydroxychloroquine, Sulfasalazine, Infliximab etc. (OPTION D) Action begins after 1 month Not recommended for acute arthritis. Bridge therapy – Start with corticosteroid and maintain the patient on DMARD. Reference: Goodman and Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th Edition, Page 842-847

questions.question: A 45-year-old female has been experiencing pain and stiffness in her wrists despite initial treatments. Her rheumatologist decides to start her on disease-modifying therapy (DMARDs). Which of the following statements incorrectly describes the mechanisms of action of the DMARDs? Methotrexate inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, reducing the production of DNA and RNA. Hydroxychloroquine inhibits T-cell activation and reduces the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines. Sulfasalazine is metabolised to 5-aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA), which reduces inflammation of joints in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) Leflunomide inhibits the synthesis of purines, leading to a reduction in lymphocyte proliferation. Infliximab is an oral DMARD that acts by inhibiting interleukin-6.
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) 3, 4 and 5 Explanation: DMARD’s No. Medication Mechanism of Action 1. Methotrexate (1) (anchor drug) Inhibition of cytokine production, chemotaxis and cell mediated immune reaction. 2. Hydroxychloroquine Block lymphocyte proliferation like chloroquine but with longer action. 3. Sulfasalazine The sulfapyridine component blocks lymphocyte proliferation. 4. Leflunomide Inhibits DHOLD (Dihydro orotate dehydrogenase) and thymidylate synthase. 5. Infliximab (I/V) Certolizumab Adalimumab Golimumab Etanercept Anti-TNF I 6. Chloroquine Inhibits IL1, IL6 TNF-Alpha in lymphocytes, reducing T cell activation. 7. Tocilizumab Sarilumab Anti-IL-6 8. Rituximab Anti-CD-20 9. Anakinra Anti-IL-1 10. Abatacept Recombinant CTLA4, inhibits CD80/86 11. Tofacitinib Janus kinase (JAK) inhibitors 12. Penicillamine Gold (Au) Azathioprine Inhibits macrophage and decreases IL-1 13. Azathioprine Cleaved to 6-mercaptopurine (6MP) and inhibit purine synthesis Reference: Goodman and Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th Edition, Page 773-774, 778, 782-790 KD Tripathi Essentials of Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page 228

questions.question: A 42-year-old female with a 3-year history of worsening joint pain presented to the clinic with early morning stiffness and swelling in her wrists. Her symptoms were not relieved with ibuprofen. A physical examination of the hands is shown. What is the most appropriate first-line treatment for her condition?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Methotrexate Explanation: Methotrexate should be used as the first line of treatment for this adult female patient with chronic pain with early morning stiffness and swelling in her wrist joints, as well as hand deformity (swan-neck and boutonnièrere deformity) in the image. Methotrexate (Anchor drug): Dose: Low dose (10-25 mg/week). Uses: Most effective drug for RA. Onset: action starts > 1 month. Contraindications: Pregnancy (neural tube defects) and lactation. Toxicity antidote: Folinic acid/ Leucovorin. Methotrexate resistance: Use anti-TNF-alpha or CD20 inhibitor. Hydroxychloroquine and Sulfasalazine are used in RA but are generally considered less effective than methotrexate for moderate to severe cases. ( Options A and B ruled out)

questions.question: A 52-year-old female patient with a known case of rheumatoid arthritis for 5 years presents to the clinic with complaints of nausea, fatigue, mouth ulcers and an unusual rash on her legs. She has been on a stable regimen of DMARDs for the past few years. Laboratory investigations reveal a decreased Hb level, elevated liver enzymes, and mild leukopenia. Which drug is most likely responsible for her current symptoms?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Methotrexate Explanation: A patient with a known case of rheumatoid arthritis on DMARDs presenting with nausea, fatigue, mouth ulcers, rash on her legs, and labs showing anaemia, elevated liver enzymes, and mild leukopenia suggests methotrexate use. It is the first-line drug used for patients with chronic rheumatoid arthritis. Side effects of methotrexate: Nausea, vomiting, and fatigue. Oral ulcers. Hair loss. Hematologic: Myelosuppression (decreased white blood cells, red blood cells, and platelets). Hepatic: Elevated liver enzymes. Hepatotoxicity. Gastrointestinal: Stomatitis (inflammation of the mouth). Diarrhoea. Other: Skin rashes. Increased incidence of chest infection. Side effects of H ydroxychloroquine .( Option A): Gastrointestinal upset. Skin rash. Retinal toxicity. Corneal opacity. Side effects of S ulfasalazine ( Option B ): Gastrointestinal upset. Rash. Liver enzyme abnormalities. Myelosuppression. The combination of nausea, oral ulcers, significant hepatotoxicity, and a decrease in white blood cell count is more characteristic of methotrexate. Side effects of P enicillamine ( Option D): Diarrhoea. Dermatitis. Drug-induced lupus. Nephrotoxicity. Reference: Goodman and Gilman's The pharmacological basis of therapeutics, 14th Edition, Page 886, 1296, 1353 KDT-Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th Edition, Page 228, 942

questions.question: A 52-year-old female with a 10-year history of rheumatoid arthritis has been on certain drug therapy for the past 5 years. She recently underwent an ophthalmological examination, where the ophthalmologist noted the presence of the following condition. What is the maximum recommended daily dose of the drug (in mg/kg) that is considered safe to minimise the risk of developing this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) 5 mg/kg Explanation: The given image shows the bull’s eye maculopathy caused by hydroxychloroquine. The recommended dose to prevent this adverse effect should not be >5mg/kg. Hydroxychloroquine Mechanism of Action Hydroxychloroquine I Lysosome Accumulation I ↑ Lysosomal pH I Inhibits Antigen Processing I ↓ Antigen-MHC Presentation I ↓ T-Cell Activation I Inhibits TLRs I ↓ Pro-inflammatory Cytokines I ↓ Inflammation in RA. Uses Rheumatoid arthritis. Systemic lupus erythematosus

questions.question: A 33-year-old male patient with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) has been undergoing treatment with methotrexate for the past two years. Despite the treatment, his disease activity has worsened, prompting the addition of a newer drug. Six months later, he got married, and subsequently, the couple faced difficulty conceiving, which was attributed to the new medication. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Sulfasalazine Explanation: Sulfasalazine Mechanism of Action Sulfasalazine I Active Metabolites I Inhibits Cyclooxygenase/Lipoxygenase I ↓ Prostaglandins/Leukotrienes I ↓ Inflammation in GI Tract and Joints + Immunomodulation + Antimicrobial Effects. Uses IBD ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease. Rheumatoid arthritis. Juvenile idiopathic arthritis. Side Effects Gastrointestinal( nausea, vomiting, diarrhea). Headache. Rash. Blood disorders like leukopenia and thrombocytopenia. Liver dysfunction. Reversible infertility in males ( oligospermia ). Additional Info Administered cautiously in patients with known sulfa allergies. Monitoring of blood counts and liver function is recommended during therapy. Reference: Goodman and Gilman's The pharmacological basis of therapeutics, 14th Edition, Page 836-839 KDT-Essentials of Medical Pharmacology. 8th Edition, Page.228

questions.question: Which of the following is not a Janus kinase (JAK) inhibitor?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Alectinib Explanation: Alectinib is a tyrosine kinase and RET proto-oncogene used to treat ALK-positive non-small cell lung cancer.
